title: Caudle Cup
artist_display:
Cornelius Vander Burch (Vanderburgh)
American, c. 1653–1699
New York
description: Traditionally, a cup like this would have held a warm beverage known as caudle, a mixture of eggs, bread, oats, mulled ale or wine, milk, and spices. As indicated by its size, this cup was meant for use by a group, most likely at a special occasion where it could be passed around and its contents shared. It was probably made for the christening of Philip van Cortlandt (1683–1746) in 1683.
inscriptions:
Marked on bottom three times: CVB (cojoined inside a heart)
Engraved on body with Van Cortlandt arms
credit_line: Purchased with funds provided by the Antiquarian Society and Dr. and Mrs. C. Phillip Miller
publication_history: V. Isabelle Miller, "A Seventeenth–Century Caudle Cup" Magazine Antiques 65 (May 1954) p. 397 (ill.). Meyeric R. Rogers, "An Early American Masterwork" Art Institute of Chicago Quarterly 49 (September 15, 1955), 42–44 (ill. cover). Helen Comstock, "The John Marshall Phillips Collection" Magazine Antiques 68 (December 1955) 554–6 (ill.). Helen Comstock, "The Connoisseur in America" The Connoisseur 137 (May 1956), 215–6 (ill.). Babette Craven, "Art in Antiques" Art News 55 (Summer 1956), 12–13. Meyric R. Rogers, "American Decorative Arts at The Art Institute of Chicago," The Magazine Antiques LXXIV, 1 (July 1958), 55 (ill.). Kathryn C. Buhler, "American Silver on View in London" The Magazine Antiques 128, 3 (Sept. 1960) p. 230. Richard Came, "Pleasures and Treasures: Silver" (New York: Putnam's, 1961) fig. 9 (ill.). R. Came, Silver, (New York, 1961), 15 (ill.). David A. Hanks, "American Silver at the Art Institute of Chicago" Magazine Antiques 98 (September 1970), 418–22 (ill.). Harold Osborne ed, The Oxford Companion to the Decorative Arts (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1975) p. 742 (ill.). Milo Naeve, "The Classical Presence in American Art" (Chicago: Art Institute, 1978) (ill.). "The Classical Presence in American Art" Magazine Antiques 114 (September 1978), 496–506 (ill.). Jane Bently Kolter, "Early American Silver and its Makers" (New York: Mayflower Books, 1979) (ill.). Art Institute of Chicago "Not to be Missed" (Chicago: Art Institute, 1982) no. 13 (ill.). Art Institute of Chicago "Pocketguide" (Chicago: Art Institute, 1983) no. 54 (ill.). Milo Naeve, "Dutch Colonists and English Style in New York City: Silver Syllabub Cups by Cornelius Kierstade, Gerrit Oncklbag, and Jurian Blanck, Jr." American Art Journal 19, 3 (Summer 1987), 40–53. Roderic H. Blackburn, Remembrance of Patria: Dutch Arts and Culture in Colonial America (Albany Institute of History and Art, 1988) no. 312 (ill.). Judith A. Barter et al., American Arts at The Art Institute of Chicago: From Colonial Times to World War I (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1998), 49–50, cat. 1 (ill.). Judith A. Barter, Elizabeth McGoey, et al., American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2016), cat. 3 (ill.). Elizabeth McGoey, ed., American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2018), https://publications.artic.edu/americansilver/reader/collection/section/6, cat. 3 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Art Institute of Chicago, Masterpiece of the Month, September 1955.

Minneapolis Institute of Arts, French, English and American Silver, June 9–July 15, 1956, cat. 292.

Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Colonial Silversmiths: Masters and Apprentices, Nov. 14–Dec. 30, 1956, cat. 256.

Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Richmond, Masterpieces of American Silver, Jan. 15–Feb. 14, 1960, cat. 216.

Christie’s, London, American Silver and Art Treasures: An Exhibition Sponsored by the English-Speaking Union and Held at Christie’s Great Room, London, Aug. 24–Sept. 24, 1960, cat. 87 (ill.).

Art Institute of Chicago, The Antiquarian Society: The First One Hundred Years, Apr. 23–June 19, 1977, cat. 187 (ill.).
provenance_text: Stephanus Van Cortlandt (1643-1700) or his son Philip Van Cortlandt (1683-1746), New York; by descent to Pierre Van Cortlandt (1721-1814), New York; by descent to his granddaughter, Ann Beekham de Peyster (1778-1857); by descent to her daughter Catherine Matilda Von Cortlandt de Peyster (1818-1886); by descent to Bishop Parsons (1851-unknown); by descent to Cortlandt Field Bishop (1870-1935); by descent to his wife Amy Bend Bishop (d. 1957); given to her heir and companion, Edith Nixon (Mrs. Shirley Douglas Falcke); with James Graham and Sons, New York, by 1955; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1955.
